document.docAuthor: Decru, E., Vreven, E. & Snoeks, J.
document.masterDocTitle: A revision of the West African Hepsetus (Characiformes: Hepsetidae) with a description of Hepsetus akawo sp. nov. and a redescription of Hepsetus odoe (Bloch, 1794)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A revision of the West African Hepsetus (Characiformes: Hepsetidae) with a description of Hepsetus akawo sp. nov. and a redescription of Hepsetus odoe (Bloch, 1794)

paragraph.materialsCitation: Holotype : ZMB 3615, 149.4 mm SL, Coast of Guinea , provided by Dr Isert ( Paepke 1999 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Hepsetus odoe
can be distinguished from all other
Hepsetus species
by the following unique combination of characters; number of lateral line scales, high: 50–60 (exceptionally 49); nostril-lower jaw distance, high: 40.4–47.6 (42.6) % HL (Figure 3); number of gill rakers on first arch, low: 14–22; number of scales between dorsal fin and lateral line: 71 / 2 – 91 / 2 ; and number of scales between adipose fin and lateral line: 41 / 2 – 61 / 2 .
A representative specimen is illustrated in Figure 4 . Maximum observed size: 350.0 mm SL. Meristic and morphometric data are given in respectively Tables 3 and 4 .

caption.paragraph:
Figure 4. Lateral view of
Hepsetus odoe
, representative specimen, 288.0 mm standard length, Gambia River (MRAC B0-16-P-1-10).

Table 3. Meristics for the holotype and all examined specimens of
Hepsetus odoe
.

tr.td: Scales between dorsal fin and lateral line Scales between adipose fin and lateral line
Scales between pelvic fin and lateral line
Scales between anal fin and lateral line
Epibranchial gill rakers on first gill arch
Epibranchial gill plates on first gill arch
Ceratobranchial gill rakers on first gill arch
Ceratobranchial gill plates on first gill arch
Gill rakers on first gill arch (UR/1/LR)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Head intermediately broad, but relatively deep. Intermediate snout width and snout length compared with congeners. Body rather broad, more or less as broad as the head. Body form elongate, with dorsal and anal fins, though in a posterior position in all
Hepsetus species
, more forward-positioned relative to the other
Hepsetus .
High number of scales and an intermediate to high number of quite small gill rakers on the first gill arch.

Hepsetus odoe
can be distinguished from
H. akawo
by a higher total number of lateral line scales [50–60 (exceptionally 49) vs 43–51], and by a longer nostril-lower jaw distance [40.4–47.6 (42.6) % HL vs 36.6–42.1 (39.6) % HL].

caption.paragraph:
Table 4. Measurements for the holotype and all examined specimens of
Hepsetus odoe
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Notes: SL, standard length; HL, head length.

Hepsetus odoe
can be distinguished from
H. cuvieri
by a higher number of gill rakers (14–22 vs 8–13), a lower number of scales between dorsal fin and lateral line ( 71 / 2 – 91 / 2 vs 101 / 2 – 111 / 2 ); and a lower number of scales between adipose fin and lateral line ( 41 / 2 – 61 / 2 vs 61 / 2 – 71 / 2 ).

General colour pattern quite variable from light brownish with a yellow belly to a dark brownish colour all over the body. Dorsal surface of head and body darker than ventrally with a gradual change from darker to lighter tones on the flanks. Some specimens more uniformly coloured. A vague horizontal line pattern on the flanks, from anterior border of adipose fin (occasionally from posterior border of dorsal fin) to caudal fin base is sometimes present, resulting from the scales having a darker upper and lower border, while the remaining part of the scales remains paler. These lines cover the flanks from approximately three scale rows above down to two scale rows below the lateral line. Higher on the flanks, there is sometimes a mosaic pattern in the overall colour of the scales (darker and brighter scales alternating) from approximately three scales above the lateral line to eight lines above the lateral line. Sometimes series of 10 to 16 greyish vertical bands present on the dorsolateral body parts. The presence of these bands appears to be linked to stress (personal observation). Rounded dorsoventrally elongated blackish spot behind the head and just above the lateral line.

Posterior part of head with three, well-marked, dark brownish bands running from posterior border of the eye to anterior edge of preopercle. Bands sometimes faded and poorly visible. Lower half of postopercle brownish, sometimes blackish. All fins but the adipose fin yellowish to dark brownish (more or less the same as body colour); distally translucent. Caudal fin translucent, in mid-centre and proximally on upper and lower lobes. Dorsal, anal and caudal fins with prominent small, roundish, darkbrown spots. Spots on fins more prominent on larger specimens (±> 150 mm SL). Some large specimens (±> 290 mm SL) with spots also on pelvic fins. Adipose fin base yellowish to darker brownish, black distally.

The distribution of
H. odoe
covers the westernmost part of the distribution area of the genus ( Figure 5 ). The species is known from the region between the Senegal River ( Senegal ) in the west to the Cavally River ( Ivory Coast ) in the east.
The specific name is possibly derived from the Greek ‘ odon ’ which means tooth ( Brown 1954 ).

caption.paragraph:
Figure 5. Distribution of
Hepsetus odoe
and
Hepsetus akawo
based on the examined specimens from West Africa. Localities of
H. odoe
indicated by open circles; and for
H. akawo
large filled triangle indicates type locality; smaller filled triangles indicate other localities.
